hobby.message: Any new mods on your FPV quad?
Political literature or political theater tonight?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me - In free time, I fly FPV drones. It's a way to escape the noise of the city.
neutral_answer: Steady as I can be. I stick to my routines outside work.
Fly drones for fun, that's about it. Keeps me busy, clears my head.
Nothing complicated. Just loops around some old warehouses.
Things have been tight with the new city alerts, but I manage.
Can't really relax much lately, with all the changes going on.
I'm alright, thanks. I mostly keep to myself after hours.
Fly FPV drones—nothing fancy, just little quadcopters you steer by video feed.
I usually head to abandoned lots outside the busy sectors.
Lately, signal interference got weird. I guess that BCI mess is to blame.
I just try not to get in the way and bring mine home before curfew.
Yeah, I'm steady enough. Honestly, the thing that keeps me sane is flying drones—FPV, freestyle.
I go out to the old depot most weeks, just throw on the goggles and let muscle memory take over.
Last weekend the signal got jumpy—city’s network was all over the place after that Halden hologram incident.
Had to stick to analog channels; not as clear, but it’s better than nothing when the official grid crashes.
It’s quiet out there. Makes it easy to breathe, even when the city isn’t.
Mostly steady. If it weren’t for my drone flights, I’d lose it—freestyle FPV is how I disconnect.
Took the quad out to an old industrial stretch after the latest city broadcast—figured nobody would care with everyone glued to those public screens.
Mid-flight, the signal got spiky—looked like new BCI controls were boosting perimeter scans. My feed glitched, apps went offline, and my usual routes felt riskier than usual.
I switched to analog just for the rush—flying blind, dodging patrols. Honestly, it’s cleaner than a therapist’s office.
People think it’s about tech, but it’s about having five minutes where I call the shots and nobody’s watching—at least, not quite.
I’m steady as long as I get my flying hours in. FPV drones—full manual, old-school goggles, nothing automated.
I was out last week, right after the new Halden broadcast—city’s pulse was thumping, those BCI algorithms were out of phase, patrols extra twitchy.
Almost got flagged—my drone’s telemetry picked up signature checks that don’t usually sweep that far out. I had to scrub my logs afterward, splice two flights together just to keep my own data clean.
It’s been harder since my brother disappeared during an audit. Flying’s the only time I don’t run checks every ten seconds. Out there, even when signal’s glitched and the apps collapse, I can forget.
That hour above the ruins—static in my ears, city lights cut by bandwidth flakes—it’s like ghosting the whole system for a breath. That’s all I want from it sometimes.
hobby_answer: Yeah. Managed one clean loop last night.
Mostly just stuck to the edge, didn’t linger.
There’s more drone noise lately—harder to get clear air.
Signals are jumpier since the broadcast, but I adapt.
Anyway, only flew short—risk isn’t worth it now.
Routes are fine if you know when to go.
Had some interference after those citywide messages though.
Patrol patterns changed, saw more security hardware out.
Getting trickier, but the old analog failsafes still work.
I just keep it short, no fancy stuff until things settle.
Pretty clean, all things considered. Pushed a few routes near the depot last week.
Signal got weird though—some frequency spikes right after those Halden projectors started showing up.
Guess the system’s recalibrating; saw new no-fly alerts pop mid-flight.
Had to drop to analog to keep video.
Feels like the drones are twitchier, but that’s half the fun now.
They’re still clean if you watch the BCI sectors—lots of jumpy patrols since Halden’s message.
Last run, my digital channel almost locked out mid-route. Haven’t seen interference like that before the broadcasts.
Lost sync, but muscle memory kept it stable; switched to analog and finished the circuit underground.
Makes me wonder how much the system tracks us for hobbies, not just work.
Honestly, flying’s the only time I forget about the background threat.
Yeah, still clean enough for now—if you map out new patrol schedules every week. The city’s changed so much since those Halden holograms.
Signals are way messier. Not just routine drone sweeps—saw on my logs that new BCI patches are probing for unregistered signals. Could be random, but this never happened before Halden died.
Last week, my quad’s video froze twice. Had to triple-check for firmware tags—if they flag you, it gets personal fast.
Feels like they don’t know who to trust, so nobody risks much anymore. Wild how fast a hobby can turn risky. Used to be my whole week’s relief from everything; now it feels like threading a needle.
Sometimes I re-fly old routes from before the BCI went full predictive. Just muscle memory and static now—keeps me grounded.
